data.title: Run-Length Binary - Alien Numerals
data.statement:
A mathematically-advanced alien wants to convert Earth numbers to their own numerals.

The first two integers are 0 and 1 (same as Earth) but for larger integers each digit represents the length of a 'run' of 1's or 0's in the binary representation of the integer.

<<Examples:>> (Decimal → Binary → Alien)
2 → 10 → 11
3 → 11 → 2
5 → 101 → 111
15 → 1111 → 4
30 → 11110 → 41
143 → 10001111 → 134

The first digit can always be assumed to refer to the length of a run of 1's, with each consecutive integer implying a run of the bit (0, 1) that was not in the last run (every second digit relates to a run of 0's).

<<0>> is taken to mean 'a run of zero 1's' (0) and is the only integer to contain the digit '0' in this representation.

Since Earthlings are not comfortable with using single-symbols beyond 9, we will restrict all inputs to being less than 9-bits (n < 512)

Print the 1-digit run-length encoding of the input integer.
data.outputDescription: <<A single line :>> the integer in 1-digit run-length encoding

Print the 1-digit run-length encoding of the input integer.
Input
Line 1 : a non-negative integer n
Output
A single line : the integer in 1-digit run-length encoding
Constraints
0 ≤ n < 512
Example
Input
15
Output
4
